Official Website: http://squidsoft.net
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Humanity has just emerged from the lowest point in its collective history, and
the closest it has been to extinction since the advent of agriculture. By the
year 2304, the Coalition of humans and their alien allies the Jinu has spread
across the stars, and thought themselves powerful. But the Outsiders, an alien
empire occupying vast reaches of Rimward space, proved them wrong. First contact
between the two allies was severed, and suddenly humanity was alone. Then the
Outsiders attacked in force, and human planets and governments fell one by one.
                         It was the apocalypse.
But contrary to the beliefs of many, not all hope was lost. After five years,
a single starship, the Percival Lowell, returned from Rimward space, bringing
with it the means to nullify the Outsiders' greatest weapon. With this, and the
help of many other brave pilots, the occupying Outsiders were driven off human
               worlds and back to where they came from.
 Humanity is now trying to rebuild, and trying to regain what it has lost. The
Outsiders are finished with occupation, and now desire only to see humans
extinct.
New threats and new mysteries seem to appear every day. In the midst of it all,
civilian starships span the stars, maintaining an open threat against any new
       invasion and trying to make a few credits while they're at it.
You too have felt the lure of this; the desire for a unique freedom that most
citizens will never know, the drive to explore, the need to defend your species,
         and yes, greed for the vast wealth that is to be had.
                   It is time to take to the stars.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Welcome to the original and still the most innovative pulp science fiction
multiplayer roleplaying adventure!
Originally opened in its classic form on 19 December 1998! Reopened in its new
iteration on 28 February 2009!
All original work (including setting, non-player characters, design, source
code, all related background material, and all text) located in this game or on
the Squidsoft.net website is copyright (c) Squidsoft.net 1998-2015. Unauthorised
reproduction prohibited.
Warning: Speech in this game is largely uncensored, and sensitive individuals
may find some other players offensive. The staff is ultimately not responsible
for the words and actions of the players.
The last server reset was at Fri Jul 22 13:40:17 2016 UTC
We're on Twitter! @StarConquest for server status notifications and out-of-game
contact!
No new announcements to display.

web address.

    * Welcome to Star Conquest! *
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, Purr
the humanoid service robot, a purple photocopier, a compact red refrigerator, a
clear plastic food storage container, an insulated green cooler, and Sassie the
large fuchsia felo here.
You can go south and out.

then hopefully you do not have to worry about the beard. If you hate your beard,
Beard-B-Gone is also available.

The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of

bowl, a luxuriously soft oval amethyst rug with a gold fleur-de-lys in the
center and thick gold fringe, a personal hoverpallet, and Xavier the big silver
soldier felo here.

[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive here.
You can go out.
launch
The navigation systems are nonfunctional until their power is restored.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Shooting Star, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."
sit
You sit down.
You carefully buckle your seatbelt.
ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
[AEU | 10: Conquest Status] An AEU pilot corps liaison transmits, "Looks like
we've got some things going, but we haven't met any performance goals yet!"
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

[Accord of Free Worlds Command; Docking Bay One]
The one-person marauder "Burn, Don't Freeze", the one-person fighter "Gambit",
the one-person cargo hauler "Current Mood", the one-person supply shuttle
"Shangri-la Terraform Group 179", the four-person Accord space module transport
"Building Blocks For Adults Are Way Underrated", the two-person Accord space
module scout "Up Up And Away!", the two-person tugboat "Stick And Go", the
four-person Accord space module transport "Shadowed Sunset", the three-person
stalwart "Red In Tooth And Claw", and the vostok-class capsule "Shooting Star"
are landed here.
You can go northeast, northwest, and up.

chronometer, a metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator, a solid silver ring
engraved with dolphins, and a backpack. You are concealing a golden Feng Wo coin
purse, a black flightbag with a red shooting star on the side, a camera bag, an
asteroid hauling supply kit, a flight control scanner, a large expandable
telescoping xenology container, a black engineering tool case, a scorched metal
thigh holster, a leather briefcase, and a thick synthleather bandolier with
large pockets. Your head, face, both eyes, neck, both wrists, and both hands are
left uncovered.

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

Star! Welcome to home space!"

[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]
This small capsule is only large enough for one person. A single flight seat
molds itself to the form of its occupant, helping to ease the burden of
acceleration along with a rather underpowered artificial gravity dampening
system. The capsule's inner workings extend into the flight cabin, with the
starship's main computer right up against the back of the seat. A rather sparse
flight control board is presented claustrophobically close to the pilot's face.
It seems to lack any sort of manual control, allowing only automatic flight
profiles to be entered into an antiquated flight computer. It does, however,
possess controls to operate a single small turret. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad. The hatch appears to be locked.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive here.
You can go out.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Shooting Star, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."

palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
You stumble, then fall heavily to the floor.

A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.

A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

[Space Vermin Patrol Command; Docking Bay]
With rings of bright round lights overhead and reflective silver-colored metal
walls, this large rectangular docking bay is quite brightly illuminated. Thick
silver cables snake up and down the walls between locked control boxes
containing small but bright multicolored blinking lights, and more rings of
blinking lights delineate the individual starship parking pads. Several
silver-colored maintenance drones move between the control boxes, directing
chunky, ceiling-mounted mechanical arms bristling with odd tools from ship to
ship, performing repairs and rearmament. To the southeast is a wide doorway
marked in black and white diagonal stripes with a sign beside it reading 'Repair
& Rearm,' and to the southwest is a similar doorway marked 'Starship Supply.' A
wide doorway to the south directed by blinking lights leads toward the center of
the station.
The two-person light corvette "Little Red", the two-person heavy launch vessel
"Squeak", the reconnaissance craft "Subtle Subterfuge", the one-person fighter
"Drabayban", the one-person fighter "Starhawk", the four-person mule "Stygian
Ferry", the two-person medium transport "Gethsemane", and the vostok-class
capsule "Shooting Star" are landed here.
You see a man in a dark trenchcoat here.
You can go southeast, south, and southwest.

from the various starship systems.

[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
Even though this starship garage smells like machine oil and heavy lubricants,
it is spacious and well-lit. Massive hydraulic systems raise and lower starships
to and from the landing pad above, and technicians and mechanics in silvery gray
coveralls ensure that everything keeps running smoothly. A well-lit stairway
which leads to the pilot's lounge is here.

[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters Five]
You see a long plasteel counter, a pair of narrow bunks, a pink air foam bed
with a fluffy peachy pink pillow, a peachy pink synthcotton sheet, a hand-made
pink and dark pink flower quilt, and a soft pale purple synthcotton blanket on

Asteria here.
You can go out.
l asteria
a Tardick lizard named Asteria
This is one of the famed Tardick lizards. It has four legs: a thick, strong back
pair and a foreshortened front pair. It seems to go on all fours most of the
time, but it also stands up occasionally, using its front paws as somewhat
awkward hands. Its toes have short but sharp talons. Its skin is dark gray and
spotted with dark green, and parallel rows of silver-colored ridges run down its
back to the tip of its long tail. Its yellow eyes betray little in the way of
curiosity. A slim dark pink tongue flicks out every few seconds. It is wearing a
slim leather collar with a tag reading ASTERIA.
take asteria
You pick up a Tardick lizard named Asteria.
pet asteria
You stroke a Tardick lizard named Asteria lovingly.
wear ateria
Wear what?
wear asteria
You settle a Tardick lizard named Asteria on your shoulder, its tail curled
loosely around you.

big silver soldier felo here.

[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive here.
You can go out.
sit
You sit down.
You carefully buckle your seatbelt.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Shooting Star, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."
ftl frontier cluster
The ship is already moving.
ftl frontier cluster
The motion of the ship throws your body from side to side, but your seatbelt
holds you in place.
Once a valuable source for raw materials on the edge of Known Space, this area
is now fully mapped and lined with beacons.
move
The starship is already moving.
The motion of the ship throws your body from side to side, but your seatbelt
holds you in place.
move
The starship is already moving.
move
The starship is already moving.
Dark asteroids tumble lazily through the emptiness of space.

transponder. You are cleared to land."
power
You may not power down the ship while it is in flight.
power
You pull a large lever towards you.

leaving you in a dim silence.
out

ftl chetumal
What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.
Via general sector communication, Chetumal transmits, "Greetings, Shooting Star!
Welcome to Chetumal Orbit!"

[Starship "Fate Falls Short"; Engineering Room]
The engineering room is much cleaner and sterile than most people expect when
they first board a starship. Though there are some exposed, thick bundles of
wires running here and there, most of the actual workings of the ship are deeper
in its structure. Instead, the room is virtually bare and brightly lit, with one
wall dominated by a large graphical representation of the ship and its
components, alongside current estimates of damage levels. On the right is a
small starmap set into a wall, displaying a bare minimum of information so that
it is not a distraction to the one keeping the ship together. A simple control
board allows the operator to prioritize repairs. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is in space.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive and a swiveling black leather
gunner's chair here.
You can go north, south, up, and down.

[Starship "Fate Falls Short"; Engineering Room]
The engineering room is much cleaner and sterile than most people expect when
they first board a starship. Though there are some exposed, thick bundles of
wires running here and there, most of the actual workings of the ship are deeper
in its structure. Instead, the room is virtually bare and brightly lit, with one
wall dominated by a large graphical representation of the ship and its
components, alongside current estimates of damage levels. On the right is a
small starmap set into a wall, displaying a bare minimum of information so that
it is not a distraction to the one keeping the ship together. A simple control
board allows the operator to prioritize repairs. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is in space.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive and a swiveling black leather
gunner's chair here.

[Chetumal Spaceport; Pilot Lounge]
Sheets of tinted glass form a transparent window into the outside world around
this crescent-shaped lounge, giving you a clear view to both the landing pad and
the surrounding mountains and other Chetumalian scenery. Comfortable couches are
spaced in neat clusters for pilots to sit in as they socialize and are brought
refreshments by the attractive waitresses. Scattered close to the groups of
couches are multiple holovids tuned to the latest news, captions scrolling
around the edges. A stairway towards the back of the room has its door open and
bears a sign reading 'Garage'.
You see a gleaming granite-topped bar, a public holovid, a brightly-lit candy
vending machine, and Nova the little black CatBot here.
Ali Candan and Damien Alexander are sitting on a comfortable black leather
couch. Cesar Ysidro, Rogue Romano, and Ather Jammoa are sitting on a cushioned
stool.

[Chetumal Spaceport; North Cargo Facility]
In the midst of heavy construction going on around the perimeter of this large
cavern to expand and reinforce it, cargo trucks rumble down the road from the
spaceport exit to the east, lining up to wait their turn to load and unload
cargo at the long docks at the west end of the facility. The road is freshly
laid asphalt, and the old, crumbling docks have been recently replaced with more
modern equipment, including machines to automate the cargo transfer process and
computer consoles to keep track of it. Off to the side, a walkway lined with
concrete barriers provides safe passage for pedestrians.

Please enter your message:
[Type lines of input; use `.' to end or `@abort' to abort the command.]
Lily,
I understand you have goals and things you want to accomplish. All of us do.
Even me. Then again, some of mine are pretty lofty, but that's really not the
point.
I understand the social and financial background you grew up in and I very much
respect that. Having said that, in the two and a half years that you have been a
pilot, you've already accomplished so much more than even the ace pilots did in
the same time period.. You have more credits, more points in every category than
they did. They're still playing catch up to you. Therefore, I think there does
need to be a balance between work, socialising and cultivating relationships.
I wanted to spend quality time with you before you weren't around as often. It's
often difficult to hold long, meaningful conversations when you have to get up
every 5 minutes to rope an asteroid and while to you it may have felt like
waisting time, spending time with the one I love before I know they will be gone
or not around as much, isn't waisting time for me. It's a chance, at least for
me, to become closer and express how much I care about them before my time with
them is severely limited. 
I'm deeply sorry if you got the impression I didn't want to spend time with you.
In fact, it was the opposite. I especially didn't want to get into an argument
right before your time for work would be reduced. I'm sorry this happened and it
wasn't my intent.
Love,
*

*
*
*
*
Shule
*

they did. They're still playing catch up to you. Therefore, I think there does

I wanted to spend quality time with you before you weren't around as often. It's
often difficult to hold long, meaningful conversations when you have to get up
every 5 minutes to rope an asteroid and while to you it may have felt like

l
[Starship "Israel Hope"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a large leather couch, and a polished
rosewood bar here.
You can go south and out.
s
[Starship "Israel Hope"; Base Block]
You see a round white rattan dining table with a glass top, a dark brown rattan
dining chair with a high back with a blue cushion on it, a dark brown rattan
dining chair with a high back with a light blue cushion on it, and a blue rattan
cabinet here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.

[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
Even though this starship garage smells like machine oil and heavy lubricants,
it is spacious and well-lit. Massive hydraulic systems raise and lower starships
to and from the landing pad above, and technicians and mechanics in silvery gray
coveralls ensure that everything keeps running smoothly. A well-lit stairway
which leads to the pilot's lounge is here.

[Starship "Striking Distance"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a black leather captain's chair and a wormhole drive tracer here.
You can go up and out.

2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
C4~(rDq&^[$r?MP09Z.krP`hz?V\Pb{(Cy4jN>c!
You stumble, then fall heavily to the floor.
(3 seconds roundtime.)
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.

The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.

A lone outpost glitters in an otherwise nondescript cloud of debris.
The League's legendary shipyards hang motionless in the dark here. Once, the
stations would be all but glowing with waste heat as the Intersector
Shipbuilding Company rolled out ship after ship. Now the stations are still and
darkened, and the ISC is no more.

bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.

in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

l
[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.

[Tactical Communication] Lily Kaise transmits, "Thanks Shule wow they were nice
enough to leave me 2 percent of the FTL! Which I can repair of course!"
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
:)UjW,squ#GQ<'5y,*a;"m^j}GrL4+T|ZrX+/q64
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Striking Distance.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."

[Starship "Striking Distance"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a black leather captain's chair and a wormhole drive tracer here.
You can go up and out.

[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Lily Kaise transmits, "Fix too."
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
$;_&r:@s~<nCC/q(Mj["j/~'MX9Dj))#Tbm6PE;.
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Striking Distance.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
tra 1 ok
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Shule Elemmire transmits, "Ok."
ftl 465
This rift accelerator requires paying a toll of 7,000,000.00 EAOS credits. Do
you wish to pay this?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You transfer a toll payment to a local rift accelerator.
[Notification from Starseekers] The organization has received 2,062,410.66 EAOS
credits from a toll payment to League Rift Accelerating Solar Toll Station in
The Belt of Orion.
The computer announces, "Setting course to Asteroid Beacon Tau 465. Allowing
external rift insertion. Local rift accelerator with matching vector found."
The ship is suddenly grasped by powerful EMMs from a nearby temporary space
station.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
A door flies open in front of you, and you step through into a cramped, heavily
decorated Victorian-era room. Something about this place isn't right.

A formless mist suddenly swirls outside the viewports, then is rapidly sucked
forward into a bright wormhole in front of the ship. The wormhole blinks out of
existence, and the ship is suddenly in normal space.
The computer announces, "Autotravel cancelled."

Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the FTL flight control board.
The computer announces, "Setting course to Asteroid Beacon Tau 465. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
A formless mist suddenly swirls outside the viewports, then is rapidly sucked
forward into a bright wormhole in front of the ship. The wormhole blinks out of
existence, and the ship is suddenly in normal space.
The computer announces, "Autotravel destination reached."

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Comet Surface.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a glossy violet ceramic felo chow bowl, a
large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick gold fringe, a large
white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow with thick silver fringe, Daizey the
humanoid service robot, a compact red refrigerator, an elegant crystal decanter,
a large crystal gold-trimmed goblet of Cape Myers Paradise Vineyards Pinot
Grigio, a large blue soldier felo, and a hefty blue soldier felo kitten here.
Lily Kaise is sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow.
You can go up and out.
(You are sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick
gold fringe.)

but I think they are cute."

destination.

Slightly Up

l
[Starship "Striking Distance"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is inside the riftflow.
You see a black leather captain's chair and a wormhole drive tracer here.
You can go up and out.

[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]
This small capsule is only large enough for one person. A single flight seat
molds itself to the form of its occupant, helping to ease the burden of
acceleration along with a rather underpowered artificial gravity dampening
system. The capsule's inner workings extend into the flight cabin, with the
starship's main computer right up against the back of the seat. A rather sparse
flight control board is presented claustrophobically close to the pilot's face.
It seems to lack any sort of manual control, allowing only automatic flight
profiles to be entered into an antiquated flight computer. It does, however,
possess controls to operate a single small turret. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is at Asteroid Belt Management Station. The hatch appears to be locked.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive here.
You can go out.
(You are sitting.)

Lily Kaise lies down on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped
headboard and filmy deep purple hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a
soft periwinkle cashmere blanket, a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt,
a large periwinkle bed pillow, and a large periwinkle bed pillow on it.
Lily Kaise tunes a metachannel FTL communicator.
lie bed
You're already lying down.
wrap lily
You wrap your arms around Lily Kaise, pulling her close.
cuddle lily
You cuddle up to Lily Kaise.
Lily Kaise tunes a metachannel FTL communicator.
Lily Kaise cuddles up to you.
cuddle lily
You cuddle up to Lily Kaise.
yawn
You yawn.
Lily Kaise yawns.
kiss lily on lips
You kiss Lily Kaise on the lips.
Lily Kaise kisses you on the lips.
-Night babe.
Say to whom?
-lily Night babe
You say to Lily, "Night babe."
Lily says to you in a New Earth accent, "Nite Love."
smile
You smile.
Lily Kaise smiles at you.

it invigorates your senses.

l me
Shule Elemmire
He appears to be 26 years old. He is about six feet and two inches tall and has
olive skin. His body is athletic with muscled hips and strong calves. He has
average-sized shoulders and a wide chest. His face is average-shaped and
handsome, with a broad nose and strong chin. His lips are thin and tan and
occasionally part to reveal a set of fairly white teeth. Beneath a set of arched
eyebrows, his eyes are blue-grey and round. His shoulder-length, straight hair
is blonde and neatly trimmed over the ears and parted on the side. He has large
brownish fingernails.
 He is wearing a soft red heather cotton polo, a pair of slim black linen
trousers, and a pair of gray canvas sneakers. He is also wearing a keychain, a
metallic gold touch einrophone in a black leather phone holster, a gold
wrist-mounted chronometer, a metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator, a
solid silver ring engraved with dolphins, and a backpack. His head, face, both
eyes, neck, both elbows, both forearms, both wrists, and both hands are left
uncovered.
He is carrying nothing.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.

5~Hg|$;Ick@tlpD#yX{5N~H,^ajTg[i3CA9;[0J+

bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.

in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

Welcome to home space!"

l
[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.
(You are sitting on a black leather captain's chair.)
dockingbay
This starship has no docking bay. The bay capacity required for this ship is 40
units.

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

Welcome to home space!"

[The Torus; East Concourse]
Though the curving walls and floor of this spacious corridor seem to be made of
bare gray metal, the walls, meeting seamlessly overhead in an arched ceiling,
glow softly with a pale white light, and the floor is such that it muffles even
the heaviest footfalls. On either side of the corridor is a row of tall windows
that provides on one side a glimpse of the inner curve of the opposite side of
the Torus and, on the other, the sight of the starry black space beyond the
station.
You can go north and south.

open container

palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
take container

take salvage
You remove a "Emerald McKay" salvage container from a leather briefcase.
open container
A "Emerald McKay" salvage container is already open.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
take launcher
You remove a decoy beacon launcher from a leather briefcase.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, Kalina. Welcome to Accord space."
put container in briefcase
You put a "Emerald McKay" salvage container in a leather briefcase.

keychain, a metallic gold touch einrophone in a black leather phone holster, a

with a red shooting star on the side, a golden Feng Wo coin purse, a black
engineering tool case, a large expandable telescoping xenology container, and a
scorched metal thigh holster. Your head, face, both eyes, neck, both elbows,
both forearms, both wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.

l
[Starship "Starseekers' Defender"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad.
You see a decoy beacon launcher here.
You can go down and out.

l
[Starship "Starseekers' Defender"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on red alert. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher and a black leather captain's chair here.
You can go down and out.
(You are sitting on a black leather captain's chair.)

Enter a subject for your new post.
[Type a line of input or `@abort' to abort the command.]
A sanitation drone turns and slowly plods south.
Greetings Starseekers,
This was already sent out as a notice to org communicators, but we'll post it
here too. We'd like to welcome our newest ship: the one-person Bastille
"Starseekers' Defender" to the organization's fleet of ships. A couple reminders
though. First and foremost, this ship does not have a wormhole drive. Therefore,
you will need to either tug it, or dock it in another ship to take it anywhere.
Second, and only slightly less important is that this ship can and often does
draw stronger fighters and corvettes and even escorts. Therefore, just be
forewarned of that. Other than that, have fun and happy fighting!
Regards,
Enter the body of your post.
[Type lines of input; use `.' to end or `@abort' to abort the command.]

*
Shule
*

Newest member to Starseekers' fleet

Greetings Starseekers,
This was already sent out as a notice to org communicators, but we'll post it
here too. We'd like to welcome our newest ship: the one-person Bastille
"Starseekers' Defender" to the organization's fleet of ships. A couple reminders
though. First and foremost, this ship does not have a wormhole drive. Therefore,
you will need to either tug it, or dock it in another ship to take it anywhere.
Second, and only slightly less important is that this ship can and often does
draw stronger fighters and corvettes and even escorts. Therefore, just be
forewarned of that. Other than that, have fun and happy fighting!
Regards,

Subject: Newest member to Starseekers' fleet
--
Greetings Starseekers,
This was already sent out as a notice to org communicators, but we'll post it
here too. We'd like to welcome our newest ship: the one-person Bastille
"Starseekers' Defender" to the organization's fleet of ships. A couple reminders
though. First and foremost, this ship does not have a wormhole drive. Therefore,
you will need to either tug it, or dock it in another ship to take it anywhere.
Second, and only slightly less important is that this ship can and often does
draw stronger fighters and corvettes and even escorts. Therefore, just be
forewarned of that. Other than that, have fun and happy fighting!
Regards,
Shule

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
The one-person bastille "Starseekers' Defender" and the five-person A.S.S.
tactical platform "William Dove" are landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine and a small trash can here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.

clacking and clanking goings on with this workbench in your face."

l
[Starship "Starseekers' Defender"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad.
You see a decoy beacon launcher and a black leather captain's chair here.
You can go down and out.

You see a decoy beacon launcher and a black leather captain's chair here.

peer out
You peer out...
[Old Earth; Manhattan Spaceport]
Welcome to Manhattan Spaceport! The entire place seems brand new, the glass
sparkling, the plasteel gleaming. Starships arrive and depart while others sit
on individual pads, rings of lights blinking around them as they are recharged.
Occasionally, the ground vibrates and the low rumble of heavy hydraulics is
heard as a starship is brought up from the underground garage or lowered for
extended parking below. Around the huge landing pad, wide, arched doorways
framed in brushed steel lead to various station services: Repair & Rearm to the
northeast, Supply to the southeast, Station Security to the southwest, and the
Mail Room to the northwest. In addition, a classy lighted sign over one doorway
reads, 'Pilot Lounge.' You can GO into it. There is also a doorway marked
'Liaison Office' that you can also GO into. Over the corridor to the south,
another sign reads 'Spaceport Exit and Express Train.'
There appear to be some people in the lounge.
The one-person cargo hauler "Tony's Delivery Shuttle", the three-person stalwart
"Aslan", and the two-person bolt thrower "Flash" are landed here.
You see an asteroid-shaped steel trash bin here.
You can go north, northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest,
and down.
Ali Candan waves.
Lily Kaise waves.
wave ali

Your ship 'Flash' has been automatically moved into a garage.
You follow Ali Candan out.

the word AUTOPILOT switches off.

brace
You suddenly stab your finger against a large button.

imminent. Please brace yourself."

starship shudders under laser fire. The impact seems slightly lessened by the
ship's ablative armor. Fortunately, the ship has braced itself against some of
the damage.

Beta Zzorme.'"

[Starship "Aslan"; Weapons Room]
Unlike the control room, a starship's weapon room has only one tiny viewport.
The focus of the room is a slightly miniaturized starmap, augmented with
additional spatial relationship information and various status displays. A
streamlined control board sits before the starmap, with prominent indicators for
lock status and weapon readiness. Control boards for the ship's weaponry are off
to either side, to be pulled into place at a moment's notice. Lights overhead
indicate that the ship is on yellow alert. Looking through the windows, you see
that the ship is at The Torus; Dock Alpha.
You see a swiveling black leather gunner's chair here.

[Starship "Aslan"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a black leather captain's chair, and a large
leather couch here.
Ali Candan is standing here.
You can go south, up, and out.

[Starship "Flash"; Control Room]
You see a decoy beacon launcher and a wormhole drive tracer here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
Minor Change:
Some changes to beacon drop balance today. It's time to play "good news, bad
news, good news."
 - Base credit rewards for more difficult beacons (higher than standard),
bonuses for destroying larger ships, and bonuses for destroying more numerous
fleets have all been boosted slightly.
 - More difficult beacons will be downgraded to "standard" difficulty for the
purposes of credit and point rewards if any participating ship left the sector
at any point. This rule excludes wasps and rescue pods.
 - A hazard bonus is awarded for facing particularly dangerous weapons, which at
this point includes only long-range lasers.
The end result is that real toe-to-toe fighting on a beacon drop, particularly a
higher difficulty one, should now be more rewarding, while cheesing higher
difficulties will be significantly less rewarding. The new "hazard bonus" should
help to offset situations where leaving for repairs probably isn't optional.
We'll likely continue to tweak these things for a little while.
You hear your metallic gold touch einrophone ringing.
You hear your metallic gold touch einrophone ringing.

[Starship "Aslan"; Engineering Room]
The engineering room is much cleaner and sterile than most people expect when
they first board a starship. Though there are some exposed, thick bundles of
wires running here and there, most of the actual workings of the ship are deeper
in its structure. Instead, the room is virtually bare and brightly lit, with one
wall dominated by a large graphical representation of the ship and its
components, alongside current estimates of damage levels. On the right is a
small starmap set into a wall, displaying a bare minimum of information so that
it is not a distraction to the one keeping the ship together. A simple control
board allows the operator to prioritize repairs. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is at Old Earth; Manhattan Spaceport.
You see a large leather chair, an improved temporary wormhole drive, and an
improved temporary wormhole drive here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go north and down.

then we're off."

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.

0ps)d"/45DT;/\"h`%+?^;z[N%W._"!NOe$K/<ag

l
[Starship "Aslan"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a black leather captain's chair, and a large
leather couch here.
Ali Candan is lying down.
You can go south, up, and out.
(You are lying down.)

changeolog

changelog
Recent Minor Changes:
-----
Inserted language into the profile submission system helping players keep track
of their word count, and warning them that longer profiles will take longer to
process.
   Posted 4 days, 4 hours, and 29 minutes ago
-----
Cola is no longer considered solid food.
   Posted 22 hours, 58 minutes, and 3 seconds ago
-----
Some changes to beacon drop balance today. It's time to play "good news, bad
news, good news."
 - Base credit rewards for more difficult beacons (higher than standard),
bonuses for destroying larger ships, and bonuses for destroying more numerous
fleets have all been boosted slightly.
 - More difficult beacons will be downgraded to "standard" difficulty for the
purposes of credit and point rewards if any participating ship left the sector
at any point. This rule excludes wasps and rescue pods.
 - A hazard bonus is awarded for facing particularly dangerous weapons, which at
this point includes only long-range lasers.
The end result is that real toe-to-toe fighting on a beacon drop, particularly a
higher difficulty one, should now be more rewarding, while cheesing higher
difficulties will be significantly less rewarding. The new "hazard bonus" should
help to offset situations where leaving for repairs probably isn't optional.
We'll likely continue to tweak these things for a little while.
   Posted 10 minutes and 38 seconds ago
-----
[Notification from Starseekers] 1 megacredit has been spent on the
organization's hyperwave relay rental contract.

rattling noise against the hull.

ABILITIES
--
MINOR REPAIR
   Slightly repairs a single target.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     20                Time To Use: 6 seconds
REGENERATE
   Repairs a single target over time. A slow but efficient repair.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     30                Time To Use: 4 seconds
MINOR GROUP REPAIR
   Slightly repairs your entire squad.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     40                Time To Use: 6 seconds
PREEMPTIVE REPAIR
   Disperses some minidrones for preventative repairs, which will assist other
friendly minidrones in their work.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     40                Time To Use: 12 seconds
MODERATE REPAIR
   Repairs a single target.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     30                Time To Use: 8 seconds
SQUAD RESTORATION
   Grants the squad very slow generative repair.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     40                Time To Use: 4 seconds
MODERATE GROUP REPAIR
   Repairs your entire squad.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     60                Time To Use: 8 seconds
MAJOR REPAIR
   Greatly repairs a single target.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     40                Time To Use: 12 seconds
MAJOR GROUP REPAIR
   Greatly repairs your entire squad.
   Module:     Minidrone
   Energy:     80                Time To Use: 12 seconds
PULSE
   Stuns a single target.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     20                Time To Use: 6 seconds
SCRAMBLE
   Increases the likelihood that an enemy will drop intact items.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     20                Time To Use: 6 seconds
REVERB
   Damages a single target over time.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     30                Time To Use: 6 seconds
SONIC SLAM
   Interrupts a group of enemies with a large sonic burst.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     20                Time To Use: 8 seconds
SONIC WAVE
   Decreases the accuracy of a group of enemies.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     25                Time To Use: 10 seconds
SHAKE OFF
   Makes an enemy slightly more disinclined to hit you.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     20                Time To Use: 4 seconds
GROUP PULSE
   Stuns a group of targets.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     30                Time To Use: 8 seconds
CONFUSE
   Decreases the reaction time of a group of enemies.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     50                Time To Use: 6 seconds
KNOCKOUT
   Makes a single target unresponsive indefinitely, or until it is hit.
   Module:     Sonics
   Energy:     50                Time To Use: 12 seconds
ADVANCED RESOURCE DETECTION
   Scans for various resources.
   Module:     Teslaworld
   Energy:     0                 Time To Use: 4 seconds
BULK MINERAL EXTRACTION
   Extracts minerals from the ground.
   Module:     Teslaworld
   Energy:     0                 Time To Use: 4 seconds
ACCELERATED RARE EARTHS EXTRACTION
   Extracts rare earths from the ground.
   Module:     Teslaworld
   Energy:     0                 Time To Use: 6 seconds
SIMPLE ARTIFACT EXTRACTION
   Extracts artifacts from the ground.
   Module:     Teslaworld
   Energy:     0                 Time To Use: 20 seconds

storms, and lightning flashes all across the sky many times a second.

n
[Teslatown; Finial Avenue] (inside a battlesuit)
Finial Avenue is a length of rather scorched concrete lined by the series of
tall lightning rods that gives it its name. An arching metal lattice overhead
and to either side forms a Faraday cage that keeps out electrical energy.
Scientists and technicians walk up and down the street, wearing environmental
suits which also act as Faraday cages in addition to possessing bulky cooling
units. Among these people occasionally stride even larger figures: people in
powered armor, their suits designed both for environmental protection and
intense ground combat.

[Site 146772711; Surface] (inside a battlesuit)
You stand on the surface of Teslaworld. The levels of radiation and magnetic
flux here play havoc with your battlesuit's electronics, obscuring all input in
shifting levels of white noise. The sky is obscured by dark purple clouds, which
flash several times a second with bolts of lightning. Markings on the ground
show that this area has already been explored.

[Teslatown; Faraday Plaza] (inside a battlesuit)
Faraday Plaza is so named for the immense spherical Faraday cage that stretches
over its entirety, by far the largest such construct on the planet. The massive
cage encloses Teleforce Tom's Lounge and Pub as well as the Electrostatic
Exchange.

l
[Starship "Daisy May"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at Teslatown; Spaceport Landing Pad.
You see a small yellow ball containing some rattling beads, a silky purple
cushion decorated with embroidered pale purple lotus blossoms, a glossy gold
ceramic felo chow bowl, an overstuffed sofa upholstered in brilliantly colored
patchwork fabric, a large oval white and light yellow cloth rug, and Emmylou the
humanoid service robot here.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on an overstuffed sofa upholstered in brilliantly colored
patchwork fabric.)

Lily Kaise just entered the ship.

Lily Kaise sits down on an overstuffed sofa upholstered in brilliantly colored
patchwork fabric.

from her.

from the various starship systems.

clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the FTL flight control board.
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Daisy May!
Welcome to home space!"

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]

with explosive force, biting deep into the surface of the asteroid.

toward League Asteroid Processing Nuclear Temporary Station.

destination.

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Comet Surface.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a glossy violet ceramic felo chow bowl, a
large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick gold fringe, a large
white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow with thick silver fringe, a compact
red refrigerator, an elegant crystal decanter, and Daizey the humanoid service
robot here.
Lily Kaise is sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow.
You can go up and out.
(You are sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick
gold fringe.)
Lily Kaise exclaims in a New Earth accent, "Just not over-fond of those orange
noses!"
Lily Kaise laughs.

Lily Kaise beams at you.
: smiles tenderly at you.
Shule smiles tenderly at you.
The computer reports that the asteroid is approximately three sectors from its
destination.
caress lily on back
You gently caress Lily Kaise's back.
Lily smiles tenderly toward you.
Lily Kaise massages up and down your back.
The computer reports that the asteroid is approximately two sectors from its
destination.
An obese blue soldier felo marches up.
A large albino felo wanders in from above.
A hefty blue felo kitten hums melodically to itself as it wanders in from above.
The computer reports that the asteroid is approximately one sector from its
destination.
Lily Kaise strokes the soft fur of a hefty blue sabre-toothed felo.
A hefty blue sabre-toothed felo purrs softly.
Lily Kaise strokes the soft fur of a hefty blue felo kitten.
A hefty blue felo kitten purrs and rubs its head against Lily's hand.
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "Aww stop that."
Lily Kaise laughs.
laugh
You laugh.
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "You are pet quality and all I need are
two more pets."
Lily Kaise grins.
grin
You grin.
Lily Kaise hugs a hefty blue felo kitten.
hug lily
You hug Lily Kaise.
The computer reports that the asteroid is less than one sector from its
destination.
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "If one came along with feathers, I would
be unable to resist."
nod and grin
You nod and grin.
A hefty blue sabre-toothed felo wanders out.
As the asteroid falls into the station's collection bay, your ship detaches and
heads for the docking bay.
You receive 10,105,850.78 League credits for this asteroid!
Your income is deferred until the temporary station's storage module is
transferred to a spaceport.

hauler "RockIt!". The organization has earned 799,884.94 credits.

[League Asteroid Processing Nuclear Temporary Station; Docking Bay]
The two-person hardened asteroid hauler "RockIt!" is parked here.
You see an asteroid anchor, an asteroid anchor, a coil of neutronium-threaded

use kit
You press a button on an asteroid hauling supply kit, and it quickly extends a
number of tiny robotic arms and grabs every asteroid hauling related implement
registered to you in the area.
Your asteroid hauling supply kit grabs an asteroid anchor with its tiny robotic
manipulator arms and stows it away.
Your asteroid hauling supply kit grabs an asteroid anchor with its tiny robotic
manipulator arms and stows it away.
Lily Kaise presses a button on an asteroid hauling supply kit, and it quickly
extends a number of tiny robotic arms and grabs every asteroid hauling related
implement registered to her in the area.
Lily Kaise's asteroid hauling supply kit grabs an asteroid anchor with its tiny
robotic manipulator arms and stows it away.
Your asteroid hauling supply kit grabs a coil of neutronium-threaded line with
its tiny robotic manipulator arms and stows it away.
Lily Kaise's asteroid hauling supply kit grabs an asteroid anchor with its tiny
robotic manipulator arms and stows it away.
Your asteroid hauling supply kit's tiny robotic manipulator arms, apparently
satisfied with a job well done, suddenly retract back into the kit.
Lily Kaise's asteroid hauling supply kit grabs a coil of neutronium-threaded
line with its tiny robotic manipulator arms and stows it away.
Lily Kaise's asteroid hauling supply kit's tiny robotic manipulator arms,
apparently satisfied with a job well done, suddenly retract back into the kit.
Some lights on the two-person hardened asteroid hauler "RockIt!" flash as Lily
Kaise boards it. They flash again as the airlock closes.

use anchor

anchor seeks the best angle downwards.
(12 seconds roundtime.)

the surface of the asteroid.

asteroid anchor.

and decide to move on to the next step.

You lower an asteroid anchor to the ground and press a button on its side.  The
anchor seeks the best angle downwards.
(14 seconds roundtime.)
Suddenly, an asteroid anchor leaps from your hand and buries itself in the
ground.  You feel vibrations through your boots as the anchor secures itself in
the surface of the asteroid.
use line
You begin to painstakingly secure a coil of neutronium-threaded line to an
asteroid anchor.
(52 seconds roundtime.)
You step back and look over your shoulder, and see that the line, now secured to
two anchors, stretches nicely over your ship.  Hopefully it will hold.
w

southwest.

cycle

your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.

The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
The computer announces, "Cycling complete."

ground.  You feel vibrations through your boots as the anchor secures itself in
the surface of the asteroid.
use line
You begin to painstakingly secure a coil of neutronium-threaded line to an
asteroid anchor.
(59 seconds roundtime.)
You step back and look over your shoulder, and see that the line, now secured to
two anchors, stretches nicely over your ship.  Hopefully it will hold.

then gradually sinks back to the ground and falls asleep again.

toward League Asteroid Processing Nuclear Temporary Station.

destination.

Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The starship has left a unique area of space.
The formless mists suddenly resolve into a dust-laden wind. After a moment the
dust settles, and one of the horses in front of you lets out a quiet whicker as
the carriage's wheels creak ceaselessly below.

about roids today."

and light green aquatic life and sea green and neon blue round rocks, a small
orange ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy pale pink

You can go out.
start
You push a small button, starting the shower. Hot water begins to pour over your
skin. You feel cleaner already.
Hot, steaming water continues to bathe every inch of your skin, cleansing you as
it invigorates your senses.
l me
Shule Elemmire
He appears to be 26 years old. He is about six feet and two inches tall and has
olive skin. His body is athletic with muscled hips and strong calves. He has
average-sized shoulders and a wide chest with small dark nipples. His abdomen is
flat and punctuated by a sunken navel. More intimately, he has bushy salt and
pepper pubic hair and an athletic butt. His face is average-shaped and handsome,
with a broad nose and strong chin. His lips are thin and tan and occasionally
part to reveal a set of fairly white teeth. Beneath a set of arched eyebrows,
his eyes are blue-grey and round. His shoulder-length, straight hair is blonde
and neatly trimmed over the ears and parted on the side. He has large brownish
fingernails.
 He is wearing nothing. He is also wearing a keychain, a gold wrist-mounted
chronometer, a metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator, and a solid silver
ring engraved with dolphins. His head, face, both eyes, neck, both shoulders,
chest, back, both biceps, both elbows, abdomen, both forearms, both wrists, both
hands, waist, both hips, groin, both thighs, both knees, both calves, both
ankles, and both feet are left uncovered.
He is carrying nothing.

Nominations for the forty-ninth civilian liaison term are now open!
Please use the nomination machine in your conference room to submit your own
candidacy.
We will need to fill the following positions:
Industrial Whip
Ground Squad Leader
Voice of the Corps
Space Defense Captain
If you already hold a position and you wish to pursue another term, make sure
you nominate yourself. The nomination process will last for two days before
voting begins.
The Office of the Civilian Pilot Corps Liaison

FTL Interalliance Communications Network
--
Subject: Bolt Thrower Test Results
Author: Susie Dodds
Posted: 07:55  1 February 2311 GST
--
Hopefully this will prove useful to those with the bolt launcher adaptation on
their vessel.
With the assistance of Herrik's new Bolt Thrower and my Heavy Fighter we made
our way into gamma space and proceeded to record the results of this new weapon.
The first test was with the disabling bolt, which Herrik fired at my ship. The
results were that my Coalition drive speed of 5000 Km/s was reduced by 50
percent to 2500 Km/s. Obviously, this will prove very formidable against some of
the faster Outsider and IFS ships.
We then moved on to the disarming bolt, which first had me fire a single torpedo
at the two person Bolt Thrower 'Sharpshooter'.
Having fired a disarming bolt at me, I recorded five percent damage to launcher
one, and then I fired another torpedo. There was no significant change to the
impact of my damage.
Herrik then fired a second bolt, taking launcher one to twenty six percent and
launcher two to twelve percent.
When I returned fire with another torpedo, no damage was recorded.
A final disarming bolt gave me slight damage to a turret and again, another
wasted torpedo from me saw no damage to his ship.
This test was well worth the effort and I think that the Bolt Launcher will be
our own more adaptable chain during invasions, without the concern of being a
sitting duck, unlike the chains.
Overall, and I am no expert on weapons and other ships, however I feel that this
is a weapon which will even up the field during crisis, especially during times
where we have few pilots alert and there are a number of enemy ships to deal
with.
Respectful regards,
Susie Dodds.
--
[1] Next
[2] Previous
[3] Return
[4] Reply
[5] Quit

Stations of the Accord.

You will not get Outsiders. If you got Outsiders it'd be really fucking bad.
Shooting at Tandem Pact ships is a great way to end our trade deals.

FTL Interalliance Communications Network

Subject: How to tackle a FAS (Forward Assault Station) without causing an
economic crisis for the AEU in the process.
Author: Space Defense Captain Arthur Cross
Posted: 06:03 11 January 2314 GST
--
Due to the catastrophic engagement against an IFS - FAS the 10th of January in
the year 2314, that resulted in the (unnecessary) destruction of a Gemini
Corvette, two Gunships, one Cruiser and a Mule Transport, it was suggested that
a post be made to provide guidelines on how to deal with such a threat without
wasting time and resources needlessly. Lets remember that we are here to protect
AEU interests and assets. That includes both personnel (the pilots) and
materials (our starships). And every mistake made puts both of those things at
risk. That simply won't do.
So first things first. What the heck is a FAS?
A FAS (or Forward Assault Station) is a mean heavy weapon platform launched by
an IFS starship designated Deployment Apollo, over a planet or in a sector they
are attacking. The FAS, like most of the IFS ships has powerful Long Range
Lasers (LRLs) and it will literally lay siege to the sector it's in until it's
taken out of commission. This cannot be done however, unless the station itself
is boarded by a ground combat team using an aerial fortress as insertion method
and subsequently destroyed from the inside via demo-charge. To make things more
complicated, the FAS will come with an entourage of powerful IFS starships that
will guard it zealously.
Now, even though it sounds like a suicide mission, it is not. As long as the
following three steps are followed, a coordinated, well executed attack by
civilian pilots can bring a FAS and it's support fleet down without any losses
whatsoever. 
Step 1: Intelligence -- Know your enemy. If the unfortunate pilot who stumbles
into a sector with a FAS is unable to relay workable data, and the FAS is
deployed in a sector that no Space Defense Captain can observe through an SDC
terminal, send in a single fighter to reconnoiter the threat. It is highly
probably that the FAS is supported by a cruiser class IFS starship with
designation Hades. It tends to be crewed by ace IFS personnel, and it will also
generate an interdiction field in the sector it's in. Making escape by wormhole
drive or leaving the sector impossible. So as to minimize loses, a single
fighter is all you should spare. Whichever the case, take note that IFS ships
are hard to identify as we don't know too much about them. The person who has
eyes on the targets needs scan each of the IFS ships and make note of the ship
classes as well as number designation. This alone is critical.
Step 2: Space Assault -- Clear the skies. Knowing what the threat is, prioritize
the targets. Crew and launch the appropriate number of ships to counter the
threat with the right amount of force. A combined assault of gunships and
cruisers works best to deal with the enemy vessels. Remember that it's highly
likely the area is interdicted by a Hades. It means that once you are in the
sector, you won't be able to get out until the field is down, and the whole as
you chase the Hades or other sources of interdiction, you will be under constant
fire from not only the enemy ships but the FAS as well. Strike fast, strike
true, and terminate each threat in order of priorities. If you don't have the
required crew and/or at the time it's impossible to launch a proper response due
to lack of available warships. DO NOT ENGAGE. Throwing ships in one at the time
may eventually win the battle, but it may cost us the entire war effort. Our
resources are not infinite, and we must deal more damage to the them than to
ourselves. Once the FAS stands alone. Jump out, prepare for Step 3.
Step 3: Ground Assault -- Fire in the hole! Same as step 2. Be sure to bring the
right team for the job. Minimum recommended team composition is of four Tier 5
suits. Minimum of one League suit and one AEU suit for repairs. Anything below
that puts the entire mission at risk, and as a consequence, the whole
engagement. 
Some of you might say, 'But we know this!' And to you I say, 'Good. Now make
everyone else also know this.' The results of todays confrontation with a FAS
left a lot to be desired, and now we must work our assess of to bring our
industry level above the red line before our competence is questioned. We made a
mess this time not due to lack of skill nor lack of weaponry. We simply failed
to protect our resources due to a severe lack of order, discipline and
efficiency. We can't let that happen again. Let's learn from this and do what we
are hired to do.
Arthur Cross
Space Defense Captain
26th Term
--
